tossups.question: In a novel by this author written in the 1990s, a startup CEO gives a speech about "Ordinary People" that predicted the rise of Reality TV to a model named Charlotte whose face had to be reconstructed with 80 titanium screws after a car accident. The acknowledgments section of this author's most recent novel notes how she personally donned a 200-pound diving suit to research how the book's protagonist, Anna Kerrigan, would repair battleships during World War II. One of this author's characters develops an expensive habit of consuming gold flakes to revitalize his sex drive. In that same book by this author, a 12-year-old includes (*) "Facts About Dad" alongside an examination of the use of pauses in pop music in a chapter that takes the form of a PowerPoint presentation. For 10 points, name this author of Manhattan Beach and A Visit from the Goon Squad.
tossups.answer: Jennifer Egan

tossups.question: A keynote speech given by Jen Walraven at the 2018 KDD conference highlighted how this company was using data science to make schedules. Tools developed at this company include a CDN system called Open Connect and a testing tool that randomly brings down different systems called Chaos Monkey. According to Yury Izrailevsky, a 2008 database corruption led this company to become a prominent early adopter of AWS. Kaggle contests derive from a (*) competition launched by this company whose million-dollar prize was claimed by BellKor's Pragmatic Chaos team; that BellKor recommendation model was never put into production because this company changed business models under CEO Reed Hastings to de-emphasize physical goods. For 10 points, name this video streaming company whose original productions include Orange is the New Black.
tossups.answer: Netflix [or Netflix, Inc.; prompt on Quickster]

tossups.question: Sarah Milov's "political history" of this activity was cribbed without credit by a 2019 episode of Here & Now featuring the hosts of BackStory. The Truth Initiative funds a library about this activity at a UCSF research center run by statistician and accused sexual harasser Stanton Glantz. The ANR Foundation lobbied for a pioneering 1990 ordinance on this activity in San Luis Obispo. This activity is promoted by refurbishing schools in Jordan, where it’s now more common than in Turkey. In (*) Indonesia, this activity usually involves kretek. Erik M. Conway and Naomi Oreskes argued that climate deniers adopted techniques from this activity's industry in Merchants of Doubt. To reduce this activity in Australia, Nicola Roxon pushed for plain packaging. Beverly Hills passed an early ban on this activity in restaurants. For 10 points, what harmful activity was restricted by New York's Clean Indoor Air Act?
tossups.answer: smoking [accept more specific answers like smoking cigarettes or smoking menthol cigarettes or smoking clove cigarettes; accept using tobacco; accept Center for Tobacco Control Research and Education; accept vaping or using e-cigarettes] (The ANR Foundation is the American Nonsmokers' Rights Foundation.)

tossups.question: A pop star helped pressure the government to kick auditor KPMG off the body investigating this event, which found that the French firm Arconic had lied about the Class E safety rating of a product that contributed to this event. Andrew O'Hagan's 60,000-word piece on this event challenges the narrative that Rock Feilding-Mellen and others on the KCTMO caused it due to frugality. This event was caused by a malfunction in a Hotpoint (*) fridge-freezer and was the deadliest of its kind in its country since the 1988 Piper Alpha disaster. Instructions to "stay put" during this event were problematic due to the aluminum cladding installed in May 2016. A BBC Breakfast report prompted by this event found defective sprinklers throughout council housing. For 10 points, name this June 2017 tragedy that killed 72 people at a large apartment fire in London.
tossups.answer: Grenfell Tower Fire

tossups.question: A group of artists from this country repurposed blocks used by ballistics engineers for part of the multimedia work AK47 vs. M16 and is called the Propeller Group. An artist born in this country turned household knickknacks owned by Martin Wong into the piece I M U U R 2. That Danish artist born in this country created a full-sized replica of the Statue of Liberty displayed in many separate pieces titled We the People. In a novel by an author born in this country, the narrator falls in love with Trevor while he is working on a tobacco farm near (*) Hartford, Connecticut. That novel by an author born in this country is addressed to the illiterate mother of Little Dog and is titled On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous. A communist agent from this country narrates the 2015 novel The Sympathizer. For 10 points, name this birthplace of Danh Vō ("yan vo") and Ocean Vuong.
tossups.answer: Vietnam [or Socialist Republic of Vietnam; or Cộng hòa Xã hội chủ nghĩa Việt Nam; accept North Vietnam or South Vietnam] (The Sympathizer is by Viet Thanh Nguyen.)

tossups.question: A 2007 book by law professor Daniel Kanstroom examines how agencies carrying out these title actions were granted arbitrary power in the 1954 Marcello decision. Another recent book titled for these actions shined a light on the appalling conditions of a ship called the Emancipación in the 1950s and examines a 1948 plane crash commemorated in a Woody Guthrie protest song. That Adam Goodman book notes how 90% of these title procedures were "voluntary" in the last 100 years. A 1996 (*) "responsibility" act streamlined the court proceedings that result in this action and made life harder for convicted felons. A document often called the "Autopsy" criticized Mitt Romney's stance that people should perform the "self" form of this process, which can be delayed by "deferred action," such as in DACA. For 10 points, name these actions that remove someone from a country.
tossups.answer: deportations [accept voluntary departure or self-deportation; accept repatriation; accept "Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos)"; accept Deportation Nation; accept The Deportation Machine; prompt on expulsions]

tossups.question: In 2013, Eugene Scalia argued that OSHA penalties on this company were akin to placing speed limits on NASCAR. Five years later, the SEC fined this company 5 million dollars for publicly downplaying the effect of an investigative piece by Gabriela Cowperthwaite on its valuation. In 2016, California disproportionately targeted this company by passing a bill sponsored by Richard Bloom. That bill banned breeding operations and was passed in the aftermath of the death of its employee (*) Dawn Brancheau. The Oscar-winning film The Cove criticized this company for benefiting from drive hunts. In 2017, it revamped its Florida operations by adding a VR component to an old rollercoaster called Kraken. This company's reputation was hurt by a documentary centering on Tilikum, titled Blackfish. For 10 points, name this chain of marine mammal amusement parks.
tossups.answer: SeaWorld [or SeaWorld Entertainment; prompt on Blackstone Group LP]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Kevin Wheeler has written multiple papers on this project, arguing that international agreements could be enforced with satellite imaging. This project was largely financed by the sale of low-denomination bonds under a Prime Minister who ruled from 1991 to 2012. Plans for this project in the Benishangul-Gumuz Region may have made a wrong assumption about the stability of a rock basement. In 2020, the Trump administration threatened 264 million dollars in security funding to block this project's completion. This project, which will boost the economy of the boomtown of (*) Adama, threatens to reduce supplies in another country from the already low 570 cubic meters per person per year. In 2013, this project led Mohamed Morsi to privately threaten military strikes. For 10 points, name this hydroelectric project that may reduce water flows to Sudan and Egypt.
tossups.answer: Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam [or GERD; or TaIHiGe; or Hidase Dam; or Millennium Dam; accept anything involving Ethiopian dam on the Blue Nile or Renaissance Dam; prompt on Blue Nile dam] (The 1991–2012 PM was Meles Zenawi.)

tossups.question: Northrop Grumman developed this agency’s AWIPS computer systems. This agency would have been barred from providing data in any way except "volume access by commercial providers" by a 2005 bill sponsored by Rick Santorum that was heavily lobbied for by Barry Lee Myers, who led this agency under Trump. A section of Michael Lewis's The Fifth Risk examines how former astronaut Kathy D. Sullivan, the head of this agency, hired social scientists to help it improve (*) warning messages issued from a facility in Oklahoma. The "voice" of this agency is a network of over 1,000 radio transmitters on a special VHF band. The Voluntary Observing Ship program supplements this organization’s system of 90 buoys ("BOO-ees"). It also operates some 158 radar sites across the US. For 10 points, name this organization that provides the raw data for companies like Accuweather.
tossups.answer: National Weather Service [or NWS; accept NOAA or National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration; prompt on Commerce Department] (AWIPS is the Advanced Weather Interactive Processing System.)

tossups.question: An Alex Pappademas article on "How the Cover Song Conquered Movie Trailers" credits the trend to this film's use of Radiohead's "Creep" in its trailer. The vinyl version of the soundtrack to this film incorrectly labels the second track as "Interpolation of 35 Ghosts IV." "The Gentle Hum of Anxiety" is part of the soundtrack to this film, which plays an electronic arrangement of "In the Hall of the Mountain King" during a (*) boat race at Henley-on-Thames. Critic Rob Harvilla used the phrase "drone-plus-piano-dread" to describe the song "Hand Covers Bruise," which plays during this film's opening sequence as the protagonist runs across the Harvard campus. The first film scored by the team of Atticus Ross and Trent Reznor was, for 10 points, what David Fincher film about the creation of The Facebook?
tossups.answer: The Social Network

tossups.question: Stephanie Land's memoir about her time working in this profession opens with the line, "My daughter learned to walk in a homeless shelter." A posthumously published short-story collection titled for people in this profession includes a story told from the perspective of a nurse celebrating the "wonderful X-Rays" of jockeys. That same story collection titled for this job includes a story in which a girl travels from El Paso to get an illegal abortion, titled "Tiger Bites." Connell's mother works in this job in (*) Sally Rooney's Normal People. A "manual" for people in this job titles a collection by Lucia Berlin. Skeeter investigates the disappearance of a Mississippi woman in this profession named Constantine in a 2009 novel that was turned into an Oscar-winning film starring Octavia Spencer. For 10 points, name this job that titles Kathryn Stockett's controversial novel The Help.
tossups.answer: maid [or cleaning woman; or domestic servant; or housekeeper; prompt on partial answers; prompt on the help; accept A Manual for Cleaning Women]

tossups.question: A book about this business by Bradley Hope and Tom Wright was subject to the only known lawsuit filed against book distributors based on the UK's Defamation Act of 2013. Tim Leissner's actions assisting this company eventually led to a 4.5-billion-dollar fine. A consultant for this business frequently turned off the transponder on his yacht, the Equanimity. This business names a scandal in which one of Marlon Brando's Oscars was seized by government agents. The movie The (*) Wolf of Wall Street was ironically funded through funds misappropriated by this business, resulting in one government filing charges against several Goldman Sachs execs. The fall of this business led to calls for Najib Razak to resign, including from Mahathir Mohamad. For 10 points, Jho Low siphoned off billions of dollars through what strategic development company based in Kuala Lumpur?
tossups.answer: 1MDB [or 1Malaysia Development Berhad; or Terengganu Investment Authority; or TIA]

tossups.question: In a film from this country, a blonde student listlessly picks at her food while friends of her boyfriend's parents reach over her, before exiting to call her friend at a hotel. In another film, an alcoholic from this country seeks treatment for his ulcer and is shuttled between multiple hospitals. A gangster from this country visits the Canary Islands to learn Silbo Gomero in the 2019 film The Whistlers. This country's 2019 dark comedy (*) I Do Not Care If We Go Down in History as Barbarians revisited the 1941 Odessa Massacre. A group of sports journalists investigate a nightclub fire in this country in the documentary Collective. This country's 2000s-era "New Wave" produced a film about Otilia helping Gabi get an abortion titled 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days, set during Decree 770. For 10 points, name this homeland of Corneliu Porumboiu ("po-room-BOY-oo"), the director of 12:08 East of Bucharest.

tossups.question: CLARA-W and GALENA are software packages that predict these events, and usually allow for the application of Janbu's Simplified Method to calculate risk. These events caused the majority of deaths in the 1999 Vargas Disaster, whose botched handling is what Juan Guaidó credits with delegitimizing the Hugo Chávez government. Clearcutting may have contributed to one of these events in Oso, Washington, that killed 43 people in 2014. They're not wildfires, but droughts have reduced (*) vegetation in Southern California, making these events more likely in the region's rocky soil. They're not floods, but these events often follow heavy rainstorms. Risks of these events are scanned for by InSAR, a type of Slop Stability Radar. For 10 points, name this type of natural disaster that might cause a house to fall off a cliff.
tossups.answer: mudslides [or landslides or landslips; or mud flows; or earth flows; or debris flows; prompt on mass wasting or slope movement or mass movement; do not accept or prompt on "avalanches"; accept the 2014 Oso mudslide; prompt on flash floods by asking, “what events did the floods cause?”]

tossups.question: E. M. DeLoughrey approached this concept with "allegories" like Kathy Jetn̄il-Kijiner ("JET-nil KIJ-in-er") poems. Iraq vet Roy Scranton wrote that this concept magnifies the problem of "Learning to Die." This concept could be "good, or even great" according to the Breakthrough Institute's 2015 "manifesto." Donna Haraway's Staying with the Trouble extends this concept to plantations using the spider "familiar" Pimoa cthulhu. This concept's developers Jan (*) Zalasiewicz ("YAHN zah-la-SHEV-eech") and Paul Crutzen appear in an "unnatural history" by Elizabeth Kolbert. Lewis and Maslin traced this concept to the 1610 Orbis Spike rather than the 1964 Bomb Spike. William Ruddiman and the ArchaeoGLOBE Project root this concept in the Neolithic; a "Working Group" dates it from circa-1950 nuclear tests for the International Commission on Stratigraphy. For 10 points, what concept marks human impact with a new geological epoch?
tossups.answer: the Anthropocene [accept the Homogenocene; accept the Anthropocene Working Group or AWG; prompt on Great Divergence or industrialization or climate change or similar answers by asking "what specific concept identifying the consequences?"; prompt on The Sixth Extinction or sixth mass extinction; accept The Human Planet: How We Created the Anthropocene; accept Staying with the Trouble: Making Kin in the Chthulucene or plantationocene; accept Learning to Die in the Anthropocene: Reflections on the End of a Civilization; accept "Welcome to the Anthropocene" or Anthropocene extinction; accept Allegories of the Anthropocene] (The manifesto was An Ecomodernist Manifesto.)

tossups.question: Mark Bradford exhibited a police body camera for Life Size, a 2019 piece commissioned for this city's inaugural Frieze exhibition. A museum in this city was filled with works such as Imitation of Marcel Duchamp after its artist, Noah Davis, couldn't convince other museums to lend him works for his Underground Museum. Another art museum in this city, based on the concept of "the veil and the vault," offers free admission to its extensive collection of works by Christopher Wool. Michael Govan has defended (*) Peter Zumthor's all-concrete design for this city's largest art museum. Latinx art was celebrated all across this city in the 2017 exhibition Pacific Standard Time. The stainless-steel panels on a concert hall in this city had to be dulled to stop nearby condos from overheating. For 10 points, name this city home to Frank Gehry's Walt Disney Concert Hall.
tossups.answer: Los Angeles [or LA; anti-prompt on Santa Monica] (Zumthor designed a new facility for LACMA. The Christopher Wool works are at The Broad.)

tossups.question: Ian M. White and Xùdōng Fàn found that high Q-factor sensors for measuring this quantity are improved by increasing the mode fraction that interacts with a sample, eta. The vibration of a piezoelectric transducer creates sound waves, which induce a grating in this quantity, in typical Bragg cells. In some carriers, this quantity varies with distance from the axis, such that the group velocity dispersion of an electromagnetic wave exactly balances the wave's (*) self-phase modulation. When this quantity depends non-linearly on intensity, it can cause self-focusing. In non-centrosymmetric materials, this quantity changes linearly with applied voltage in the Pockels effect. Metamaterials may have negative values of this quantity, which changes quadratically in the optical Kerr effect. For 10 points, uniaxial crystals have two values of what quantity due to birefringence?
tossups.answer: index of refraction [or refractive index; accept dielectric constant; prompt on relative permittivity or birefringence before read; prompt on n; accept refractive index sensors; prompt on double refraction]

tossups.question: Commercial growth of this plant shot up after Gerrit van Duijn ("KHAIR-it fon down") launched Project Paddington in the 1990s. The Environmental Investigation Agency decried the lax standards in "sustainable" plantations growing this plant certified by the RSPO. This plant has been widely grown in one country following the introduction of the pollinating weevil E. kamerunicus. In 2018, Iceland Groceries had to go back on its pledge to remove a product derived from this plant from all its food. Plantations growing this plant have been driving the (*) Sumatran orangutan to extinction and now account for the plurality of both carbon emissions and exports from Indonesia. Hershey claims its use of oil derived from this plant’s seeds and fruit does not come from exploited peatlands. For 10 points, name these plants that include the species planted on Los Angeles highway medians.
tossups.answer: palm trees [accept oil palms; accept palm oil; accept Arecaceae; accept Elaeis; accept Attalea or maripa palm; accept Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil; prompt on trees; do not accept “Ericaceae”]

tossups.question: A recent Financial Times exposé about this industry found that Cornell University helped Bernard Bergemar gain control over it. Jon Ronson explored this industry's changing business models in the first season of his podcast, The Butterfly Effect. Until 2012, the largest convention for this industry was held concurrently with CES in Las Vegas. A company called MiKandi operates this industry's largest app store. The largest company in this industry removed all (*) unverified content after a 2020 New York Times investigation centered on MindGeek. A 2019 UK law required this industry to enforce photo IDs and gave new regulatory powers to the British Board of Film Classification. In recent years, this industry has been disrupted by the rise of sites like RedTube. For 10 points, name this industry whose websites were the intended use of the domain suffix .xxx.
tossups.answer: pornography industry [or sex industry; or adult film industry; or equivalents; do not accept or prompt on the "film" industry as none of the clues really apply to that industry]

tossups.question: One book set in this city details how Maya, despite having a master's degree, is forced to cook meals for her in-laws and give up her cell phone. "Love and Marriage" in this city are documented in Elizabeth Frock's book The Heart is a Shifting Sea. A pivotal moment in one book set in this city comes when a one-legged woman sets herself on fire after a dispute involving ceramic kitchen tiles. That book set in this city derives its title from a message on the billboard that divides this city's international airport from a prominent slum. The life of a garbage collector in this city is chronicled by Katherine (*) Boo's Behind the Beautiful Forevers. It’s not Agra, but hotels in this city lost business after a November 2008 incident where the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel was attacked by Lashkar-e-Taiba terrorists. For 10 points, name this most populous city in India.
tossups.answer: Mumbai [or Bombay]

bonuses.leadin: The 1993 book New Families, No Families? claims that boys raised by single mothers are much more likely to chip in during these tasks. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: household chores [or housework; or household tasks; accept equivalents; accept specific chores like washing the dishes or laundry]
University of Michigan Institute for Social Research [or ISR]
Likert scale [accept Rensis Likert]
parts: Identify these activities that men have doubled their participation in since 1976. Arlie Hochschild coined the phrase "second shift" for women being assigned these activities after work.

This University of Michigan organization has collected longitudinal data on household chore participation and educational attainment. A study from this organization's Panel Study of Income Dynamics tracked children's time use from 1983 to 2003.
The founder of the Institute for Social Research names this now-ubiquitous survey scale, which respondents answer from "strongly disagree" to "strongly agree."

bonuses.leadin: This pianist collaborated with Finnish vocalist Tarja Turunen on a recording of Schubert's Ave Maria. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Yiruma [or Lee Ru-ma; prompt on Lee or I]
K-pop [or Korean pop; prompt on boy bands]
Láng Lǎng [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this contemporary pianist who is best known for pop-classical pieces like "Kiss the Rain" and "River Flows in You."
Yiruma has made many collaborations with artists in this ubiquitous genre of pop music, including Ailee, 2AM, and Shinee. Its major acts include BIGBANG and BTS.

This prominent Chinese classical pianist has collaborated a few times with K-pop artists, such as performing the "Moonlight Sonata" to open a performance by B2ST ("beast") at the 2011 MAMA festival. He performed at the 2011 White House State Dinner honoring Hú Jǐntāo's visit.

bonuses.leadin: This Mexican state was the only one exempted from a 1997 US ban on avocado imports. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Michoacán (“mee-cho-ah-KAHN”) [accept State of Michoacán de Ocampo or Estado de Michoacán de Ocampo]
Viagra [or sildenafil; accept Los Viagras]
maquiladoras (“mah-KEEL-ah-DOR-as”) [or maquilas]
parts: Identify this state that now exports about 2.4 billion dollars' worth of avocados. A 2008 grenade attack by the La Familia cartel killed 8 people in its city of Morelia.

Among the cartels fighting for control of Michoacán's lucrative avocado trade is one named for this brand-name prescription medicine, once advertised by Bob Dole and Pelé. There's a thriving market for "herbal" alternatives to this "little blue pill."

Elsewhere in Mexico, favorable US trade policy led to the proliferation of these facilities. Nintendo quashed a unionization effort at one of these facilities in Cananea that made parts for the Game Boy Advance. Give the Spanish term.

bonuses.leadin: This author argued that women authors were relegated to a lower-status section of the bookstore in her 2012 essay "The Second Shelf." For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Meg Wolitzer
Lysistrata
Nora Ephron
parts: Identify this author who wrote of the feminist Greer Kadetsky in her novel The Female Persuasion and of a group of friends who met at Spirit-in-the-Woods camp in The Interestings.

In Wolitzer's novel The Uncoupling, a new drama teacher at Eleanor Roosevelt High School stages this Aristophanes play, which is appropriate because a cold wind has caused all women in the novel to stop having sex.

Wolitzer's novel This Is Your Life was adapted into a film by this director, who described having "a morass of loose Tic Tacs, and solitary Advils" in "I Hate My Purse," part of her essay collection I Feel Bad About My Neck.

bonuses.leadin: Singapore suffered a severe 2005 outbreak of this virus, which binds to the mannose receptor of macrophages. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: dengue virus [accept dengue fever or breakbone fever; prompt on Dengvaxia]
sylvatic cycles [sylvatic transmission cycles; or jungle cycles]
domestic pigs [or swine; accept pork; accept suids; accept Sus; accept African swine fever virus or ASFV]
parts: Name this mosquito-borne flavivirus that has been endemic to Southeast Asia and the American tropics since the 1980s. In 2017, the Philippines recalled a Sanofi Pasteur vaccine for this virus that caused children without prior infections to become severely ill.
Dengue and yellow fever undergo these enzootic ("enzo-otic") "cycles," which chart their transmission among wild animals like monkeys. This term is distinct from zoonosis.

Sylvatic Trichinella differs from strains infecting these domestic animals, which have died from an "African" fever in Bulgaria and China. Muslims in Scotland have refused flu vaccines that contain gelatin from these animals.

bonuses.leadin: This author reported optimistic stories such as the group Otpor! opposing Milošević in Join the Club: How Peer Pressure Can Transform the World. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Tina Rosenberg
John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation [accept MacArthur Genius Grant]
transgender youth [or being young or equivalents; accept pubescent or people undergoing puberty; or children or kids or teenagers or similar answers] (GnRH agonists are used as puberty blockers.)
parts: Name this author who profiled the lingering impact of Poland and Czechia's Soviet satellite periods in The Haunted Land: Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism. She also edits the "Fixes" column in The New York Times.
Tina Rosenberg received a fellowship from this foundation, commonly called a "Genius Grant."

Kristina Olson won a 2018 MacArthur Fellowship for collecting longitudinal data on people who are transgender AND have this other characteristic. Trans people with this characteristic are disproportionately likely to be homeless, and controversially may take GnRH agonists.

bonuses.leadin: This author invited Paula Deen to help cook an accurate antebellum dinner after the scandal over her racist plans for a "Southern plantation wedding." For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Michael W. Twitty
Sierra Leone [or Republic of Sierra Leone; accept Salone]
spinach [accept Spinach oleracea; accept baby spinach]
parts: Name this culinary historian who traced the impact of the African diaspora on Southern foodways in The Cooking Gene.

Michael Twitty located a precursor of his grandmother's red rice recipe in the cuisine of this country's Mende people. '90s-era conflict in this country inspired Aminatta Forna's The Devil That Danced on the Water and Ishmael Beah's A Long Way Gone.

Sierra Leone's cuisine includes a variant of palaver ("puh-LAV-er") sauce, which often dresses this vegetable used in quiche Florentine. In 2019, Salmonella contamination prompted Dole to recall the "baby" form of this iron-rich green.

bonuses.leadin: A New York Times piece noted that the premiere summer event for these people in Pennsylvania had declined from 30,000 participants in the 1990s to 6,000 in 2018. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: American Civil War reenactors [accept Confederate reenactors or Union reenactors or generic answers like historical reenactors; or equivalents; prompt on LARPers or live-action role play participants]
Pickett's Charge [prompt on George Edward Pickett]
Shelby Foote [or Shelby Dade Foote Jr.]
parts: Identify these people. One of these people named Rob Hodge was particularly celebrated for his grotesquely swelling belly in a 1998 book by Tony Horwitz that examines varieties of them like Farbs.

In Confederates in the Attic, Horwitz participates in a reenactment of this failed Confederate operation named for a commander who states, "General Lee, I have no division" near the end of the 1993 film Gettysburg.
Horwitz also interviewed this Confederate-sympathizing historian featured in Ken Burns's The Civil War. He wrote the three-volume history The Civil War: A Narrative.

bonuses.leadin: In 2018, the UK Supreme Court ruled that these arrangements must be available for heterosexual couples as well. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: civil partnerships [or domestic partnerships; or civil unions; or registered partnerships]
The Netherlands [or Nederland; anti-prompt on Holland]
Theodore Olson [or Ted Olson; or Theodore Bevry Olson]
parts: Identify these legal arrangements that began as alternatives to granting marriage rights to same-sex couples.

Marriages are only four times more popular than registered partnerships in this country. Since 2016, institutions in this country have stopped using the term "allochtoon" ("all-okh-TONE") to refer to people of non-Western ancestry.

This man, who would have been Tom Brady's lawyer had he decided to appeal the Deflategate ruling to the Supreme Court, argued against the constitutionality of California's Prop 8 eliminating same-sex marriage rights. From 2001 to 2004, he served as US Solicitor General.

bonuses.leadin: Yú Wùfēi's New York Times op-ed about the "revenge" of these animals noted that the Táng-era herbalist Sūn Sīmiǎo advised not to eat their meat, which is now marketed as "wild tastes." For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: pangolins [accept scaly anteaters, but do not accept or prompt on "anteaters"; accept Pholidota; accept Manidae; accept Manis; accept Smutsia; accept Phataginus; accept specific pangolin species]
red [accept IUCN Red List or International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List of Threatened Species]
Hángzhōu [or Hangchow]
parts: Name these mammals traded for their scales in China. Although SARS-CoV-2 probably originated in bats, scientists have found similar viruses in these mammals that resemble anteaters.
All eight pangolin species appear on the IUCN’s list named for this adjective, which tracks the extinction risk of threatened species.

Pangolins were allegedly sold at a wet market in Wǔhàn. In 1999, all roadside wet markets were banned in this other Chinese city of some 21 million people, which contains the prestigious Zhèjiāng ("juh-jyong") University.

bonuses.leadin: Ned Block joked that, owing to its popularity, this paper's thesis "was false in 1995 but is true now." For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: "The Extended Mind" [accept Extended Mind Thesis or EMT] (by Andy Clark and David Chalmers)
Lev Vygotsky [or Lev Semyonovich Vygotsky]
Martin Heidegger
parts: Name this influential 1998 philosophy paper which posits that Tetris players perform "epistemic actions" and describes how tools like books and slide rules support human abilities.
Andy Clark's work on the "The Extended Mind" drew on studies of childhood development by this Soviet psychologist, who formulated the zone of proximal development.

Michael Wheeler argued that the Extended Mind Thesis had its philosophical foundations in this earlier philosopher's "radically non-Cartesian account of everyday cognition." This philosopher's controversial Black Notebooks were published in 2014.

bonuses.leadin: Andy Serkis starred as a talking anus in a PSA that advocates only using the "three P's" to prevent these objects from forming. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: fatbergs
liposuction
lidocaine [accept Xylocaine or Lignocaine; accept 2-(Diethylamino)-N-(2,6-dimethylphenyl)acetamide]
parts: Give the specific term for these objects. One weighing over 400 tonnes was found near Birchall Street in Liverpool in 2019.

Fatbergs are produced from saponification, the same process used to make soap. The artist Julian Hetzel once had visitors wash their hands with human-derived soap extracted during this fat removal procedure, the most common plastic surgery.

Liposuction patients are often given high volumes of this anesthetic. In a common intro organic chemistry lab, this compound is synthesized from 2,6-dimethylaniline that undergoes nucleophilic acyl substitution followed by an SN2 reaction.

bonuses.leadin: The van Breukelen group at this university uses tenrecs to model hibernation. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: UNLV [or University of Nevada, Las Vegas; prompt on University of Nevada]
telemedicine [or telehealth; accept telecommunications]
dermatology [accept skin doctors; accept dermatoscopy]
parts: Name this land-grant university whose Boyd law school opened in 1998, leaving Alaska as the only state without a law school. This school's campus features the Lied Library and Architecture Studies Library.

Students at the UNLV medical school perform virtual dissections on Sectra "tables," exemplifying this remote form of "medicine" that includes virtual house calls and e-rehab. Its four-letter prefix comes from a form of electronic "communications."

FotoFinder sells telemedicine imaging software for this medical specialty. Advocates have called for the end of the racist Fitzpatrick scale in this field, which increasingly treats "prickly heat," or miliaria ("mill-ee-AIR-ee-uh").

bonuses.leadin: In 2019, students at this university voted to add a 27.27-dollar fee to tuition to pay reparations for descendants of enslaved people sold by this university in the 1830s. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Georgetown University
Nikole Hannah-Jones [or Nikole Sheri Hannah-Jones; prompt on Nikole Sheri Hannah or Nikole Sheri Jones]
Providence, Rhode Island (The mayor is Buddy Cianci.)
parts: Identify this Jesuit university now in Washington, D.C., the first university to receive a federal charter.
In the wake of the George Floyd protests, this journalist wrote the piece "It Is Time for Reparations." She won the 2020 Pulitzer Prize for Commentary for her work on "The 1619 Project."

In June 2020, this city's mayor, Jorge Elorza, established a committee to investigate reparations. The podcast Crimetown documented mob influence in this city under a mayor indicted following the FBI's Operation Plunder Dome.

bonuses.leadin: This stuff often contains high levels of ammonium, strontium, and barium sulfate. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: fracking wastewater [accept produced water; prompt on water or H2O; accept fracking fluid]
earthquakes [or EQs; or tremors; or temblors]
dynamic triggering [or dynamic stresses; accept remote triggering; accept dynamic strain aging]
parts: Name this toxic substance that would be treated at a proposed plant on Seneca land in Coudersport, Pennsylvania. An excess of this stuff has led to it being spread on icy New York roads and dumped in pits in California's Central Valley.
In Oklahoma, fracking wastewater "injection wells" have caused a surge in these disasters by destabilizing faults.

A 2013 Science paper found that wastewater injection caused transient seismicity described by this adjective, since it was triggered by large, distant quakes in Chile and Japan. In materials, this adjective describes "strain aging" that induces the Portevin–Le Chatelier effect.

bonuses.leadin: This architect integrated existing buildings into his Education Centre for the painters Arthur and Yvonne Boyd. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Glenn Murcutt [or Glenn Marcus Murcutt]
prefabricated [or word forms; accept readymade construction; prompt on modular architecture or modular design]
corrugated iron [accept Fe; or corrugated galvanized iron; or corrugated steel] (The structure in Parc Güell is a fence.)
parts: Name this Australian architect whose Islamic Centre in Melbourne is the subject of the documentary Spirit of Place. This 2002 Pritzker winner specializes in designs that modify vernacular elements to reduce their environmental impact.

Murcutt's 1994 Marika-Alderton House was constructed in this fashion. The Indian firm KEF Infra One has an assembly line that can mass-produce homes and cafeterias in this fashion for assembly on-site.
Murcutt revived interest in the use of this material in architecture. Palm leaves decorate a structure made from this material that was moved to Parc Güell in the early 20th century.

bonuses.leadin: A recent push to end this conflict was assisted by an exercise in which European diplomats taught representatives from each side how to eat fondue. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Western Sahara conflict [accept anything involving the war in Western Sahara even though that specific term often refers to an earlier conflict; accept Independence Intifada; accept the conflict between the Polisario Front and Morocco or equivalents]
John Bolton [or John Robert Bolton]
an airport [prompt on an island or the Canary Islands or Lanzarote; accept Lanzarote Airport or César Manrique-Lanzarote Airport or Aeropuerto de César Manrique-Lanzarote]
parts: Identify this long-simmering territorial conflict. Building on the Abraham Accords, the Trump administration recognized one side's disputed claims to territory in this conflict in December 2020.
This mustachioed one-time National Security Adviser under Donald Trump and notorious hawk unsuccessfully tried to resolve the Western Sahara conflict.
Aminatou Haidar, the so-called Sahrawi Gandhi, won international support for staging a hunger strike at one of these places in 2009 after refusing to accept "Moroccan" as her nationality.

bonuses.leadin: During this period, Egyptian viewership of the nightly mosalsalat TV serials almost doubles. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Ramadan [or Ramazan; or Ramathan]
Judaism [or Jewish]
Suleiman the Magnificent [or Suleiman I; or Suleiman the Lawgiver; or Süleyman-ı Evvel; prompt on Suleiman]
parts: Identify this season when some 140 new television series fought for prime advertising rates in 2017. In 2018, Kalabsh was a breakout hit during this season.

The 2015 Ramadan series Harat al-Yehud featured one of the first positive depictions of a member of this religious faith on Egyptian TV in the character of Moussa Haroun, who founds a kibbutz after a 1948 war.

An estimated 150 million people watched Halit Ergenç (“AIR-gench”) play this man on the show Muhteşem Yüzyıl (“mookh-teh-SHEM yooz-yill”). In 2012, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan announced he'd prosecute the show's producers for their portrayal of this man.

bonuses.leadin: The cover of this novel features Peter Hujar's wincing photograph Orgasmic Man. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: A Little Life
Bulgaria [or Republic of Bulgaria; or Republika Bǎlgariya]
Milan Kundera
parts: Name this long 2015 novel by Hanya Yanigahara that follows a group of four male friends in New York, including the traumatized abuse victim Jude.

A Little Life was heralded as a "great gay novel" by Garth Greenwell, whose debut novel What Belongs to You is mainly set in this country. Miroslav Penkov, Alek Popov, and Maria Popova are authors from this country, whose horned kukeri costumes appear in the film Toni Erdmann.
A Village Voice review compared Georgi Gospodinov's Bulgarian novel The Physics of Sorrow to this author, but "with ADD and potty jokes." He wrote The Unbearable Lightness of Being.

bonuses.leadin: In 2019, Mighty Earth released a report calling Cargill "the worst company in the world" because it was contributing to widespread deforestation in this region. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Cerrado
soybeans [or soya bean; or Glycine max]

aquifers [accept fossil aquifers; accept the Guaraní aquifer; accept the Nubian Sandstone Aquifer System; prompt on the Great Man-Made River or GMMR by asking "what natural features is it supplied by?"]
parts: Identify this tropical savanna adjacent to the Amazon Rainforest, and to the southwest of Brazil's arid caatinga shrublands and Atlantic dry forests.

Cargill buys large quantities of this crop from farms on clear-cut land in the Cerrado. Following a trade war with the US, China has increased Brazilian imports of this crop, which is used to make tofu.

The Cerrado is also the site of the world's second-largest example of these features, which is named for the Guaraní people. A "fossil" one of these features was important to a massive infrastructure project in Libya.
